title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from the Philippines engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Philippines?
preds: but media may well claim- that the 'bizarre breed' of noi are Philippine citizens

I am a Filipino and at that I hail from the southern island of Mindanao where the conflicts usually break out. I do have a good understanding of the socio-political forces at play that causes these conflicts to erupt resulting to deaths. 1'000 killed civilians in a systematic manner by one of the separatist groups is a pretty tall order. The recent Marawi siege which was one of the worst armed conflict in recent years claimed barely a 100 civilian lives. In addition, I consider three major factors in making my forecast. First, the recent ratification of the Bangsamoro Organic Law (BOL) which grants more self government amongst islamic citizens in the south is a strong factor to pacify the separatist groups. Second, the martial law extension in the island being approved by the congress and subsequent judicial challenge ultimately rejected by the Supreme Court, is widely seen by the citizens of the south positively. Finally, after a generally peaceful midterm elections, the most overwhelming endorsement to Duterte's rule came from the South with an average majority of about 70% and in some key strategic regions reaching as high as 90%, which is unprecedented in our electoral history, tells me that at least for as long as the Duterte government enjoys a very high confidence in the south, chances of conflict outbreaks leading to civilian deaths would be indeed slim.
Religious conflict or ridding society of 'criminals.'

The people like Duterte. Can’t recall if he ever followed through on war declaration against Canada over garbage... while the numbers may be satisfied from war on drugs, the wording of question unlikely to be satisfied.
No significant changes since last forecast.

Aside from a terrorist incident in late January that took the lives of 20 civilians, there has been a noticeable lack of attacks, both on civilians and the military. Thus, this seems to be an isolated incident. Abu Sayaff, the ISIS-funded terrorist group in the Philippines, is losing traction as the Islamic States loses power in the Middle East, especially in former strongholds such as Syria and Iraq.

Philippine armed groups currently appear to include Communist rebels, Islamic militants and government forces. Communist rebels have mainly attacked government forces in the past and it seems highly unlikely they would systematically target civilians. Government forces have previously targeted  Communist rebels and Islamic militants but generally not civilians and it appears highly unlikely that they would do so. Islamic militants may target non-Muslim civilians in sporadic attacks but are unlikely to kill 1000 civilians in the remaining 11 months.

Although there was a terrorist attack in the Philippines in late January that took the lives of 20 civilians, this appears to be an isolated incident or a very lackluster terrorist operation. Since then, there have been no major attacks on civilians nor military targets in the Philippines. The terrorist group operating in the Philippines, Abu Sayaff, is a splinter group supported by the Islamic State. The weakening of the Islamic State in the Middle East is a possible cause for the group's lack of activity in the Philippines and this will continue to occur as they lose more territory in Syria and Iraq. The organization has begun using suicide tactics, utilizing foreign fighters, which could lead to the possibility of increased civilian casualties. 
https://thediplomat.com/2019/02/the-changing-dynamics-of-islamist-terrorism-in-philippines/
These are peaceful and resourceful people but they are struggling with climate change and poverty
Expect ISIL to become a force in Asia.

IS in the Philippines isn't dead, but they're pretty shit at large scale terrorism. Their presence is also largely confined to predominantly Muslim areas. I take it you're not including Duterte's anti-narcotic death squads in this toll, because otherwise that number would probably already be over 1000.

Leadership in the Philippines is known for its strongly violent stance toward drugs, drug users, and criminals. "Death squads" were actively implemented during his tenure as a lower level leader, so I would suspect that the state may actually be the driver here. If not the state, ISIS/ISIL has somewhat of a foothold in the Philippines, and if the state begins to act against the citizens, many of them may turn to ISIS for protection, thus strengthening a militant force that has been known to kill many people.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 (also see that comment for ambiguity regarding "mass killing campaign") Other judgments:
- EWP estimate at 1.3% [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 1%. Inside view: 
- EWP list an ongoing mass killing campaign in the Philippines: "The government of the Philippines’ state security forces and associated vigilante groups began cracking down on suspected drug users and sellers (along with other suspected political enemies) in a coordinated campaign of mass killing in 2016. In July 2016, the government launched “Operation Double Barrel” to carry out the president’s campaign promise to wipe out all “drug personalities.” Human rights groups estimate the death toll since President Rodrigo Duterte took office to be well into the thousands." [2]
- There seems to be significant sectarian violence in the country's south, despite a deal giving Muslims autonomy rights. [3] [4] This deal seems to have mainly disarmed the Moro Islamic Liberation Front [5], but not the groups affiliated with Islamic State. However, there seems to have been a strong government response and the US is also involved somehow [6]. I'd very, very surprised if this escalated into a mass killing.
- I also don't expect the government to engage in another episode of mass killing. Elections are coming up soon and I couldn't find anything on associated violence. This would again be very, very surprising. Overall judgment:
- EWP seems to be about right here. I'd say 2%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/philippines
[2] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/ongoing-mass-killing
[3] https://www.voanews.com/a/violence-resurfaces-in-philippines-despite-autonomy-deal-with-muslims/4591061.html
[4] https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2184233/philippines-violence-two-killed-grenade-attack-mindanao
[5] https://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-philippines-muslim-autonomy-2018-story.html
[6] https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/asia-pacific/islamic-state-on-the-rise-in-philippines-as-it-dwindles-in-middle-east-1.3822034
